answer.text_box: It has made it easier to find information online. Nothing important to me though because most times it is inaccurate. AI has also made me more untrustworthy of videos/pictures online, you now have to question if things are generated.

displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: Most describe a net-positive shift driven by productivity and convenience, while a noticeable minority voice skepticism or harm, and some say the impact is modest so far, treating AI as an optional tool.

  • Common uses and benefits:

  • Research and learning: faster answers, better summaries, explanation of complex topics, tutoring for math/coding/languages, and deeper exploration of interests.
  • Writing and communication: drafting and refining emails, proposals, resumes/cover letters, social posts, and improving grammar/spelling; greater clarity and brevity.
  • Organization and planning: event/trip planning, brainstorming, tables/lists, recipes, personalized recommendations, and general time management.
  • Creative work: inspiration and overcoming writer’s block; image editing, art generation/enhancement, shirt designs, and video; helps visualize ideas and iterate quickly.
  • Work and business: automating repetitive tasks, drafting policies/terms, market/pricing research (e.g., e-commerce), better productivity and perceived effectiveness.
  • Personal life: mental health support and advice, conflict perspective-taking, smart-home control, health/fitness and skincare guidance, homework help and improved grades, side gigs and income ideas.

  • Entertainment: stories, fun prompts, AI videos, and exploration of random facts.

  • Downsides and concerns:

  • Accuracy and bias: outputs sometimes wrong or irrelevant; requires fact-checking and source scrutiny; perceived source bias.
  • Privacy and data use: discomfort with tracking, data retention, and potential misuse of personal information.
  • Authenticity and trust: deepfakes, fake images/videos, difficulty discerning what’s real; anxiety and reduced trust in online content and creative works; challenges for educators to uphold originality.
  • Job security: fear of displacement or deskilling, especially in creative and knowledge roles.
  • Overreliance and originality: worry about diminished critical thinking, creativity, and personal voice; some intentionally limit usage.
  • Social and environmental impacts: algorithm-driven addiction, degraded social media experience, and concerns about environmental costs.

  • Friction and saturation: AI is ubiquitous even when benefits feel marginal; mixed quality or “sometimes helpful” experiences.

  • Behavioral shifts:

  • Many default to AI as a first step for answers, brainstorming, and drafts, then verify with traditional search.
  • Increased vigilance in spotting AI-generated content; some actively avoid AI on ethical grounds.

  • Users balance efficiency gains with efforts to maintain originality and independent thinking.

  • What would improve trust and value:

  • Better accuracy and transparent sourcing.
  • Stronger privacy protections and data controls.
  • Norms and guardrails in education and workplaces that encourage genuine work while leveraging AI responsibly.
  • Regulation to address deepfakes, misinformation, and broader societal risks.
  • Tools that augment human creativity and skills without encouraging dependency.

Bottom line: AI is widely viewed as a capable assistant that accelerates work, learning, and creativity, delivering meaningful time savings and confidence. At the same time, people are grappling with accuracy, privacy, trust, and job-related risks, prompting a desire for responsible use, safeguards, and a balanced approach that preserves human originality.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments

  • General sentiment: Most comments describe meaningful, often substantial benefits from AI, especially around efficiency and learning, alongside persistent worries about privacy, authenticity, and job security. A smaller share report little to no change or prefer to avoid AI.

  • Positive impacts

  • Productivity and time savings: About 60–70% say AI streamlines routine tasks, drafting, formatting, summarizing, and research, making work and school faster and easier.
  • Research and search: Around 50–60% value concise answers, synthesis, and better query handling, though many still verify with traditional search.
  • Writing and communication: Roughly 40–50% use AI for emails, resumes, proposals, social posts, tone refinement, grammar/dictation cleanup, and clearer explanations.
  • Creativity and design: About 25–35% use AI for brainstorming, overcoming writer’s block, image editing/generation, layout ideas, and video content.
  • Learning and tutoring: Around 30–40% cite help with concepts, math, coding, languages, and study support—often describing AI as a “free tutor.”
  • Personal life and organization: 20–30% mention trip/event planning, recipes/meal plans, home automation, tables/calendars, and personalized recommendations.
  • Well‑being and support: A smaller group (about 5–10%) note emotional support, perspective-taking in conflicts, and mental health encouragement.

  • Business uses: Several mention e-commerce listings/pricing, policy drafting, side gigs, and workflow optimization.

  • Concerns and drawbacks

  • Accuracy and bias: About 10–15% flag hallucinations, biased or limited sources, and the need to fact-check AI outputs.
  • Privacy and data use: Roughly 20–30% express worry about tracking, data harvesting, and surveillance—sometimes tied to smart-home uses.
  • Job security and displacement: About 10–20% fear replacement or diminished roles, especially in creative and educational fields.
  • Authenticity and skill erosion: Around 10–15% worry about overreliance, declining critical thinking/originality, and difficulty teaching genuineness.
  • Trust and deepfakes: Approximately 15–25% feel less trusting of online content, cite AI-generated fakes, or actively avoid AI-made media; a few see AI as “theft.”
  • Social media effects: Some describe more addictive feeds and difficulty finding real people or authentic creators.
  • Environmental impact: Mentioned occasionally as a broader societal concern.

  • Mixed tool quality: Some note dictation quirks and uneven usefulness across tools and time.

  • Adoption patterns

  • Many treat AI as an everyday assistant; others see it as an optional tool for ideas or quick lookups; a notable minority report minimal impact or deliberately avoid AI.

  • A significant portion explicitly cross-checks AI outputs with external sources.

  • Net takeaways

  • The prevailing view is net positive: AI increases efficiency, expands access to knowledge, and boosts creativity. At the same time, concerns about privacy, authenticity, deepfakes, and employment temper enthusiasm.
  • Commenters implicitly call for better accuracy and source transparency, stronger privacy protections, thoughtful regulation (especially around deepfakes), educational guidance to preserve human originality, and reliable AI-content detection—so people can benefit without sacrificing trust or autonomy.

Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: Most describe a net-positive shift driven by productivity and convenience, while a noticeable minority voice skepticism or harm, and some say the impact is modest so far, treating AI as an optional tool.
